channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pope Francis Wades Into U.S. Immigration Morass With Border Trip
item.description: The Times will be blogging about the moment Francis steps to the edge of the border at Ciudad Juárez, Mexico.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: A priest left shoes worn by migrants at the site along the United States-Mexico border where Pope Francis will celebrate Mass on Wednesday.

item.title: News Analysis: Uganda, Firmly Under One Man’s Rule, Dusts Off Trappings of an Election
item.description: The pressure for multiparty democracy seems to be fading in African politics, but many longtime leaders feel the need to go through the motions.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Supporters of Uganda’s president, Yoweri Museveni, waited for his arrival at a rally in Kampala, the capital, this week.

item.title: China Deployed Missiles on Disputed Island, U.S. Says
item.description: The Pentagon has evidence that China has deployed surface-to-air missiles on one of the Paracel Islands in the South China Sea, a U.S. official said.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Part of the county-level Chinese district, Sansha, on Woody Island in the Paracel chain.

item.title: France’s Emergency Powers Spur Charges of Overreach From Muslims
item.description: Critics of the state of emergency say the human cost of warrantless searches has been disproportionate to their efficacy.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: France Keyser for The New York Times
item.media:description: Daoud Muradyan, who is blind, in his house in Avignon, France. He was placed under house arrest under the state of emergency declared by President François Hollande after the Nov. 13 terrorist attacks in Paris.

item.title: Sinosphere: China Telescope to Displace 9,000 Villagers in Hunt for Extraterrestrials
item.description: Thousands of villagers in Guizhou Province are being relocated to make room for a $184 million telescope to detect signs of alien life.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: The radio telescope under construction in Guizhou Province. The building project, known as FAST, is estimated to cost about $184 million.

item.title: Editorial: A Tale of Horror at the United Nations
item.description: The organization is failing some of the world’s most vulnerable children by not cracking down on sexually abusive peacekeeping troops.
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.media:description: United Nations peacekeepers in the Central African Republic.

item.title: Veto Likely to Block Renaming of China Embassy’s Street After Liu Xiaobo
item.description: President Obama is expected to prevent the renaming of the street where the Chinese Embassy sits in honor of a Nobel Peace laureate jailed in China.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The Chinese Embassy in Washington, whose address would honor a jailed Nobel Peace laureate under a bill approved by the United States Senate.

item.title: Hong Kong Students Who Protested Government Now Seek to Take Part in It
item.description: A group of young students seeking greater autonomy for Hong Kong is forming a political party to participate in local elections this year, a move that is likely to unnerve Chinese leadership.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Joshua Wong, left, and Nathan Law, center, outside the Wan Chai Police Station last August in Hong Kong.

item.title: US Stealth Jets Fly Over S. Korea Amid N. Korea Standoff
item.description: Four U.S. F-22 stealth fighters flew low over South Korea on Wednesday in a clear show of force against North Korea, a day after South Korea's president warned of the North's collapse amid a festering standoff over its nuclear and missile ambitions.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea delivering a parliamentary address on Tuesday.

item.title: Nicolas Sarkozy Placed Under Investigation on 2012 French Election Charges
item.description: Mr. Sarkozy, the former president, was questioned on Tuesday by judges and notified of the preliminary charges for exceeding the limit for electoral spending.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Spaniard to Face U.S. Trial in Art Scandal
item.description: The national court ordered the extradition to the United States of Jesús Ángel Bergantiños Díaz, accused in a major art market scandal that involved the sale of nearly $70 million in forged paintings through a New York gallery.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: F.D.A. Issues Zika Virus Guidelines for Blood Supply
item.description: The Food and Drug Administration is advising some blood banks to import blood from regions without an outbreak and certain at-risk donors to delay making a donation.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE SAINT LOUIS

item.title: Eagles of Death Metal Return to Paris for Concert
item.description: The band that was playing at the Bataclan when gunmen killed 90 people there returned to Paris. The show included survivors.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and BENOIT MORENNE
item.media:description: Eagles of Death Metal, who were playing at the Bataclan concert hall in Paris when terrorists killed 90 people there on Nov. 13, performed at the Olympia in the French capital on Tuesday.

item.title: Pope Francis Entreats Mexico’s Youth to Resist Call of Drug Cartels
item.description: Francis delivered a searing indictment of the Mexican underworld, urging the nation’s youth to value themselves and resist the temptation to join forces with groups “that sow terror.”
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and JIM YARDLEY

item.title: U.N. Says Aid Delivery Near in Syria for 5 Towns
item.description: Turkey said it was in talks with allies including the United States about a ground war operation. American unwillingness to commit troops made prospects unlikely.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: The Turkish Army, stationed on Tuesday near Kilis, in south central Turkey, fired toward the Syria border as Turkish officials called on Western allies to join for a ground war against Syria.

item.title: World Briefing: Zimbabwe: Owner of Impounded Jet Says Body on Board Was a Stowaway
item.description: The American corporate owner of the cargo jet impounded in Zimbabwe after the bloodied body of a man was discovered aboard during a refueling stop confirmed that man was a stowaway.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.S. Had Cyberattack Plan if Iran Nuclear Dispute Led to Conflict
item.description: The plan, named Nitro Zeus, was designed to disable Iran’s air defenses, communications systems and parts of its power grid but was suspended after the deal was fulfilled.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: Ukraine’s Prime Minister, Arseniy Yatsenyuk, Survives No-Confidence Vote
item.description: Mr. Yatsenyuk faced wavering allies in the party of President Petro O. Poroshenko, who had called on him to resign.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Israeli Officers Briefly Detain Two Journalists
item.description: The Washington Post’s Jerusalem bureau chief and a colleague were detained after being accused of “inciting” Palestinians while conducting interviews outside the Old City.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: The Israeli border police briefly detained the Washington Post correspondents William Booth, right, and the contract writer Sufian Taha, center, at Damascus Gate in Jerusalem on Tuesday.

item.title: German Police Raid Property of Group Linked to ISIS
item.description: More than 200 officers and intelligence agents raided an office and 12 homes in the northern city-state of Bremen to enforce a ban on a Salafist group.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
